newsitem.title: UK: Cocoa ministers plan meeting in Gabon.
newsitem.headline: Cocoa ministers plan meeting in Gabon.

text.p: Ministers from key cocoa producing states will meet in the West African nation of Gabon on October 21-22 to review the 1993 international cocoa pact, a senior pact official said.

The meeting, to be preceded by the annual assembly of the 12-member Cocoa Producers' Alliance (CPA) on October 14-18 in Gabon's capital Libreville, will be the first such meeting since 1993, CPA secretary-general Silas Kanga of Cameroon said.

"We will look into the developments affecting world production and review the 1993 agreement," he told Reuters over the weekend at the end of the week-long International Cocoa Organisation (ICCO) talks.
He declined to give further details.
The London-based ICCO administers the five-year producer-consumer accord, an administrative pact that replaced the previous 1986 economic agreement.
The last CPA ministerial meeting in 1993 was held in Ivory Coast, the world's top cocoa grower. Other major CPA members include Brazil, Ecuador, Ghana, Malaysia and Nigeria.
At the ICCO talks, producer and consumer members agreed to cut world cocoa production by a small 90,000 tonnes over the next three years to help balance world supply and demand.
Importing nations, led by the European Union (EU), had opposed a producer call for a bigger cut, saying that the move could severely disrupt cocoa supplies to its processors.
The ICCO meeting also approved a budget of 2.89 million stg to finance the secretariat's 1996/97 administrative budget, an ICCO spokeswoman said on Monday.
But it deferred to the next meeting in December a decision to set up of a reserve fund to finance the secretariat after its Buffer Stock sales run out in April 1998, she told Reuters.
The meeting also appointed Ivorian Commodities Minister Guy-Alain Gauze as the new ICCO council chairman for a one-year term. He succeeds Jan Van Sluisveld of the Netherlands.
